stream_context.summary: Kaze works on multiple star-select screens (menu backgrounds) and related UI/animation code, importing and fixing Biobak’s assets, adding/adjusting fog, tile scrolling, and a minecart animation that follows spline points. The stream includes key N64 technical constraints (coordinate limits causing hardware crashes, microcode choices, material settings that break on emulator), plus a notable update about ROM space savings for streamed music and candid talk about finances and compensating collaborators.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete N64 constraints (33k coordinate crash), pipeline/material pitfalls (nth_color, fog/material vs global fog), a full implementation/debug arc for the minecart-on-spline star-select animation, ROM-space breakthrough enabling more streamed music, and candid discussion of finances and compensating Biobak.

findings.summary: Kaze shares major life changes: moving into a new house next week and starting a new job as a 3D modeler (described as “for the government kind of”).

Kaze identifies a hard N64 stability constraint: rendering objects outside roughly the ~33,000 coordinate range can crash real hardware, forcing him to shrink/bring in star-select background elements rather than extending them further into the distance.
findings.quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.

findings.summary: Microcode choice matters for performance/visual scale: using regular F3D makes certain displacement effects much larger than intended and renders slower; he checks backgrounds to ensure they use the intended “Sneaky microcode” setup.

Material/export settings can break on emulator: he removes/avoids using "nth_color" because it can cause meshes to go invisible on emulator; he also ensures materials are set to opaque and adjusts texture formats/combiner expectations.
Kaze notes fog is “basically free” to add, but the fog setup must be correct (material vs global fog). He troubleshoots why fog wasn’t appearing as expected on a star-select background.
He decides not to rely on certain tooling for optimization: Fast64-driven texture scrolling is described as “so unoptimized,” so he implements scrolling manually in code instead.
findings.quote: I don't want to add the scrolling with Fast64 because it's just so unoptimized if you do.

findings.summary: Kaze implements and debugs a minecart element for a star-select screen: spawns the minecart, moves it along spline points based on distance-per-tick, adds pitch/tilt, and adds wheel texture scrolling; he iterates through logic bugs (divide-by-zero, casting order, interpolation direction).
He actively resists over-detailing menu backgrounds, arguing that adding too many elements becomes visually noisy and “ruins the elegance,” preferring restrained, readable star-select compositions.
findings.quote: There's a very tempting force to just add more and more stuff until it's just a clusterfuck of stuff, but it kinda ruins the elegance of the background.

findings.summary: For the Crystal Cave star-select concept, Kaze likes Biobak’s animated background and suggests glowing crystals as a “cherry on top,” but flags that they may complicate lighting and may need to be skipped if they disrupt the look.

He attempts a pragmatic rendering fix for star-select backgrounds: adding a separate gray plane/element to fill the buffer and prevent undesirable edge/clear artifacts, rather than attaching it directly to the background model.
Kaze reveals very low recent channel income (example given: about $6.90 last month plus “a little bit” on Patreon), influencing how much he can pay collaborators despite wanting to compensate them.
findings.quote: My YouTube channel last month, $6.90 and a little bit on Patreon.

findings.summary: Kaze and Biobak discuss compensation explicitly: Biobak jokes about pricing ($5 per vertex) and mentions being “starving”; Kaze responds seriously that compensation is reasonable, offers to discuss after stream, but cannot match a real job wage.
findings.quote: If you want to discuss pay after the stream, we can do that. I definitely can't pay you like a real job.

findings.summary: Kaze reports a ROM-space breakthrough for streamed music: Arctic found that STRM64 can trim unused post-loop audio, saving ~1.7MB ROM space and enabling more streamed tracks than the team expected.
He hits tool/pipeline friction: Fuzz64’s tooling unexpectedly inserted a “water skybox segment” into his level, which Kaze fears will break compilation and requires immediate cleanup/workaround.
findings.quote: Fuzz64 added the water skybox segment to my level… This is gonna cause my game to not compile.

findings.summary: Kaze frames the session as meaningful progress toward an upcoming boss fight presentation, implying the star-select/boss-fight-facing polish is part of the current development push (though not fully completed on-stream).
findings.quote: Great progress on the boss fight we did today.

biobak.summary: Biobak supplies multiple star-select background concepts and animations (including Crystal Cave and Bubble Dome), plus layout feedback (e.g., moving text down because it wasn’t vertically centered).
Biobak’s assets include a minecart/track element at a very large scale relative to Mario; integrating it prompts Kaze to adjust placement, movement, and rendering order/alpha interactions.
Biobak compiles “Kaze quotes” for potential sticker packs and drives the idea of matching Yoshi expressions/colors to streamer in-jokes.

zeina.summary: Zeina joins briefly, bantering with Kaze about shared memes (the “happy happy cats” song) and how their social feeds/algorithms have become dominated by cat content; she also discusses sticker-pack quote ideas and what will/won’t land with a broader audience.

findings.summary: Arctic improves STRM64 usage by trimming unused audio beyond loop points, saving ~1.7MB ROM space and expanding the project’s budget for streamed music tracks.
Fuzz64’s tool/process unexpectedly injected a water-skybox segment into a level, creating a potential compile-break and forcing Kaze to intervene mid-stream.

Lilaa provides frequent UI/layout feedback (e.g., centering text, list of quotes), suggests tooling/debug approaches Kaze dismisses, and participates in the running compensation discussion (e.g., joking about a GoFundMe).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There's a very tempting force to just add more and more stuff until it's just a clusterfuck of stuff, but it kinda ruins the elegance of the background.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains his restraint-first approach to menu/background art direction and readability.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.
memorable_quotes.context: Hard technical boundary that shapes how far backgrounds, fog, and large props can extend in the scene.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I do not want to play a video game, I want a second life in Mario 64 PC port.
memorable_quotes.context: Joking but revealing comment about scope creep fantasies and the allure of expanding SM64 into a ‘world’ rather than a set of levels.

key_stories.title: The 33k coordinate crash forces a redesign of the star-select background
key_stories.summary: While integrating a star-select background, Kaze realizes the planned depth/tiling pushes geometry too far from the origin. He explains that exceeding the N64’s safe coordinate range can hard-crash hardware, so the background must be shortened and fog brought nearer.
key_stories.challenge: Make a seamless, distant-looking star-select background without triggering N64 hardware crashes.
key_stories.process: Kaze checks microcode/material assumptions, measures scene coordinates, reduces repeats/scale, and repositions elements to stay within safe bounds.
key_stories.outcome: Background depth is reduced (“half the size”), but the design becomes safe for real hardware and cheaper to render.
key_stories.key_quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.

key_stories.title: Minecart-on-spline star-select animation implemented through debugging
key_stories.summary: Kaze adds a minecart element to the star-select screen and makes it move along a path defined by spline points. The implementation requires multiple debugging passes (interpolation logic, indexing, divide-by-zero, casting, and pitch direction), plus optional wheel scrolling.
key_stories.challenge: Translate a Blender concept (tracks + minecart) into stable in-game movement and appealing motion for the star-select UI.
key_stories.process: Spawn minecart, compute distance-along-spline per tick, find bracketing points, interpolate position, add pitch/tilt, tune speed, and test render ordering/alpha issues against the background.
key_stories.outcome: Minecart motion works and visually supports the star-select composition; Kaze notes remaining polish (scroll quality, tilt behavior).

key_stories.title: ROM budget expands due to STRM64 trimming
key_stories.summary: Kaze reports that Arctic discovered unused audio past loop points in streamed tracks and can trim it. The savings (~1.7MB) increases how much streamed music the project can afford to include.
key_stories.challenge: Limited ROM space constrained how many streamed songs the hack could include.
key_stories.process: Arctic updates STRM64 workflow to cut post-loop audio data that isn’t needed in-game.
key_stories.outcome: More streamed music becomes feasible than previously planned.

key_stories.title: Collaboration meets financial reality
key_stories.summary: A joking conversation about paying Biobak escalates when Biobak says he is “starving.” Kaze responds seriously, shares his low monthly YouTube revenue, and says Biobak should be compensated even if it can’t be a full wage.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing fair compensation with extremely limited project income.
key_stories.process: Kaze offers to discuss pay after the stream and acknowledges payment is reasonable; he contextualizes constraints with actual revenue numbers.
key_stories.outcome: Compensation remains unresolved on-stream but becomes an explicit follow-up topic for the team.
key_stories.key_quote: I definitely can't pay you like a real job. But you should be compensated somewhat.

key_stories.title: Tooling friction when a skybox segment appears uninvited
key_stories.summary: Mid-development, Kaze notices a “water skybox segment” has been added to a level by Fuzz64’s tooling. He reacts strongly because such injected segments can break compilation and derail work.
key_stories.challenge: Unexpected tool-side changes introduce compile risk and confusion.
key_stories.process: Kaze pauses to inspect what happened and indicates he must remove/avoid the injected segment.
key_stories.outcome: Issue is identified as an external-tool problem; cleanup is necessary before normal work can continue.
key_stories.key_quote: This is gonna cause my game to not compile.

open_questions.topic: Boss fight progress referenced at the end
open_questions.context: Kaze says there was “great progress on the boss fight” today, but most of the stream shows star-select/background work plus earlier mentions of a dark Blargg and Mario falling through platforms.
questions: Which boss fight is this (Blargg?) and which course/area is it tied to?
What specifically was improved today: visuals, collision reliability, phase logic, camera, or UI transitions?
What are the remaining blockers (e.g., collision bugs like Mario falling through platforms)?
How do star-select screens and boss-fight presentation tie together in the player experience (narrative/flow)?

open_questions.topic: Coordinate-limit crash knowledge and how the team validates real-hardware safety
open_questions.context: Kaze cites a coordinate boundary (~33k) that can crash N64 hardware and adjusts assets accordingly.
questions: What is the exact technical reason for the crash (fixed-point precision, RSP/RDP limits, matrix overflow)?
How does Kaze test and reproduce these crashes—on EverDrive, emulator, or both?
Do they have internal guidelines for artists (Biobak/Zeina) to prevent out-of-range scenes early?

open_questions.topic: Microcode strategy across the project (F3D vs ‘Sneaky microcode’)
open_questions.context: Kaze checks backgrounds’ microcode and claims regular F3D makes displacement larger and slower.
questions: What is ‘Sneaky microcode’ in the project’s context (custom build, F3DEX variant, configuration)?
What are the decision rules for choosing microcode per level/menu element?
Are there compatibility tradeoffs on real hardware or certain emulators?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 vs custom code pipeline rules
open_questions.context: Kaze avoids Fast64 for certain effects (texture scrolling) due to optimization concerns; he also complains about unwanted segments being inserted by tooling.
questions: Which parts of the pipeline are allowed to use Fast64, and which are ‘must be custom’ for performance/clean output?
What recurring problems have they had with Fast64/Fuzz64 tooling (injected segments, unoptimized display lists, material flags)?
Do they maintain internal documentation for contributors on export settings (e.g., nth_color, opaque)?

open_questions.topic: Streamed music plan after STRM64 ROM savings
open_questions.context: Arctic’s change saves ~1.7MB and allows more streamed tracks than expected.
questions: How many streamed tracks do they now plan to include, and which areas/levels get them?
What is the quality/performance impact (CPU time, streaming bandwidth, memory buffers)?
How is music sourced/commissioned and approved (Badub workflow)?
How do they decide which tracks are streamed vs sequenced/MIDI-style?

open_questions.context: Kaze discusses low income and wanting to compensate Biobak; chat jokes about fundraising; Kaze mentions paying musicians as a ‘plan.’
questions: What is the current compensation model for Biobak/Badub/Zeina/other contributors (rev share, fixed payments, informal)?
Has Kaze considered Patreon tiers, sponsorship, donations earmarked for collaborators, or other funding routes?
How do financial constraints affect scope decisions (cutting features, reusing assets, fewer animations)?

open_questions.topic: Crystal Cave star-select lighting and ‘glowing crystals’ idea
open_questions.context: Kaze loves the concept but worries glowing crystals will ‘mess with the lighting quite a bit.’
questions: What lighting approach does the project use overall (static lights, faked point lights, custom engine)?
What exactly breaks when adding emissive/glow-like elements on N64 (combiner complexity, light limits, draw order)?
Would they consider a cheaper illusion (billboards, texture animation) rather than true lighting?

open_questions.topic: Minecart animation design goals and final polish
open_questions.context: Kaze makes the minecart follow spline points, adjusts speed, pitch, and wheel scrolling but dislikes the scroll look and some tilt behavior.
questions: What was the intended feeling for the minecart (fast thrill vs gentle travel) and how does it reflect the level theme?
How will they finalize the minecart motion (easing, banking, camera-relative motion)?
What performance budget does a star-select screen get compared to in-level gameplay?

open_questions.topic: Bubble Dome star-select improvements and asset replacement
open_questions.context: Kaze praises Bubble Dome’s distant dome look and says a ‘marine’ asset looks better than the current in-level version; he questions whether foreground lights should be removed.
questions: Will Bubble Dome’s star-select establish narrative travel/preview of the level (like ‘you’re traveling there’)?
What criteria decide whether decorative lights stay or get removed (readability vs spectacle)?
What is the process for replacing in-level assets with improved versions discovered during menu art passes?

open_questions.topic: House move + new job impact on development pace
open_questions.context: Kaze is moving next week and starting a new 3D modeling job.
questions: How did the move/job change available dev time and scheduling for streams?
Did the job influence tools/skills used in RTYI (modeling pipeline, optimization habits)?
How does Kaze balance long-term ROMhack scope with life stability (burnout prevention)?
